column1: #RobbieGallagher	unknown-#RobbieGallagher-party	unknown-#RobbieGallagher-dob	unknown-#RobbieGallagher-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-06-15 00:00:00	Gnó an tSeanaid - Business of Seanad	1	I welcome the Minister of State and thank him for taking time out of his busy schedule to be here. I wish to raise the registration of rights of way and the coming deadline of November. I understand there are two methods by which rights of way can be registered. One is that the person who requires the right of way can contact the landowner or owners and ask them to sign an easement which can be lodged with the land registry. Alternatively
column2: the person seeking the right of way can lodge an application with the land registry
column3: which in turn contacts the landowner or owners
column4: and if there are no issues
column5: the person seeking it may go ahead and register the right of way. There is a deadline of November pending for the registration of rights of way. I suggest the deadline be extended for several reasons
column6: the main one being the public is simply not aware of it. People are not aware of what will happen or what they will have to do to register a right of way after that date. There is also the pandemic
column7: which meant most businesses were closed. Those who were aware of the deadline did not have the opportunity to address the issue of rights of way because of the lockdown. I wish to raise two related issues. Local authorities granting planning permission in areas where there are public walkways is an issue around the country. They grant planning permissions without being aware a right of way exists
column8: perhaps a public walkway or beach front. There are examples which have caused friction in communities. I suggest the Department could issue a directive to all local authorities advising them that prior to granting planning permissions
column9: they should be cognisant of any rights of way
column10: and where there are local rights of way
column11: the local authorities should take on the responsibility of registering them. It should not be left to members of the public to go through the expensive and arduous procedure. There have been delays in requests for registration based on possession. I am aware it can take up to five or seven years for the process to complete. Will the Minister of State shed any light on the nature of the problem causing the delay? Is it staffing or something else? There is clearly a problem and there has been for some considerable time. I would like responses to these
column12: but in particular around the deadline that is coming in November and the lack of awareness among the public. They need to be made aware of it and advised what the procedure will be after November. I hope the Minister will extend the deadline and initiate an awareness campaign so that people know the changes and when they will happen.

column8: Local Government and Heritage
column9: who has responsibility for the Property Registration Authority of Ireland
column10: PRAI. The Minister for Justice understands from the PRAI that the following is the position. First
column11: the extension of the transitional period of three years originally prescribed by section 38(b) of the 2009 Act by the 2011 Act
column12: which extends the period to 12 years
column13: relates simply to the period when a claim to a prescriptive right can be made by reliance on the "old" law replaced by the 2009 Act. From 2021
column14: reliance must be made on what can be termed the "new" law introduced by the 2009 Act and
column15: in particular
column16: reliance must be made on the new single and shorter period of 12 years. There is no question of a cut-off point occurring in 2021 when a claim to a prescriptive right can no longer be made. All that changes in 2021 is the basis on which the prescriptive right can be claimed
column17: and that is the shorter period. Second
column18: the new procedure for registration of a prescriptive right introduced by section 41 of the 2011 Act is not subject to a time limit. It is a permanent procedure and
column19: in particular

column24: acquired by prescription. If all parties agree to the registration of an easement
column25: an application should be made by lodging the appropriate deed of grant. The Department has received correspondence
column27: requesting an amendment to section 38 of the Civil Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2011. The Department of Justice is currently in the process of arranging discussions with official stakeholders on this topic. The Department is assessing the situation. However

column30: that is more a matter for the Department of Housing

column34: and I have seen similar situations arise in Wexford. I will bring to the attention of the Minister
column36: the concerns around delays in registrations with the PRAI. While
column38: it is a matter more appropriate for the Department of Housing
column40: it is an important issue and I will raise it with the Minister for Housing

column1: #RonanMullen	unknown-#RonanMullen-party	unknown-#RonanMullen-dob	unknown-#RonanMullen-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-06-15 00:00:00	Gnó an tSeanaid - Business of Seanad	15	Having listened to the contribution made by Senator Eugene Murphy
column2: with which I agree
column3: and the response made by the Minister of State
column4: I was reminded of a line that may have been incorrectly attributed to the late Dr. Garret FitzGerald. He was reputed to have objected
column5: on one occasion
column6: to a policy measure on the basis that while it was all very well in practice that it would not work in theory. As the Minister of State will be aware
column7: the Personal Injuries Assessment Board
column8: PIAB
column9: was established in 2003 to try to divert personal injuries claims from the courts
column10: reduce legal costs
column11: reduce the pressure on the courts system and relieve upward pressure on insurance premiums. As we also know
column12: to knowingly or recklessly give false statements in any court
column13: either in direct evidence or by affidavit
column14: amounts to perjury
column15: which is a very serious offence that carries substantial sentences. The gravity of this offence is underlined in the Criminal Justice (Perjury and Related Offences) Bill 2018. It was originally sponsored by my former Seanad colleague
column16: Pádraig Ó Céidigh
column17: and I hope that the Bill will pass its final Stages in the House this afternoon. While the legislation deals with the situation in the courts
column18: it is a remarkable fact that while the PIAB process was intended to be a substitute of sorts for the courts
column19: there appears to be no legal penalty of any kind for making false or misleading statements in an application to the board for a claim of damages. In 2019
column21: 500 applications were made to the board and 11
column23: 000 applications were rejected by PIAB each year for the past several years as being unmeritorious for whatever reason and deserving of no award of damages. Therefore
column24: PIAB rejects well over 60% of all applications each year.Nobody is suggesting all these rejected applications were false or misleading because there can be many factors involved in the rejection of a claim but
column25: given the sheer number of rejected claims
column26: it is difficult to believe all of them were based on the truth
column27: the whole truth and nothing but the truth. Since personal injuries actions are regularly rejected by the courts based on false and misleading evidence
column28: there is a likelihood that a substantial proportion of claims rejected by PIAB were based on allegations that were shown to be false or not wholly true. While perjury in a court of law runs the risk of prosecution and a serious penalty
column29: there appears to be no penalty whatsoever in law for making a false or misleading claim to PIAB. The Personal Injuries Assessment Board Act 2003 and the very substantial amending Act in 2019 place no positive duty on claimants to tell the truth and do not even contain the words "false"
column31: or any words like them. That is extraordinary given the onus of honesty that is correctly placed on applicants to other State agencies. The Nursing Homes Support Scheme Act contains stringent provisions against the making of false or misleading claims to the HSE. There is a penalty of up to three months in prison or a fine of €5
column32: 000 for knowingly or recklessly giving false or misleading information. When dealing with the Revenue Commissioners or the Department of Social Protection
column33: applicants have to make regular and repeated commitments regarding the truth and accuracy of their applications. When getting a jobseeker's benefit or jobseeker's allowance
column34: an applicant has to sign a declaration stating he or she is out of work and is a genuine claimant. This must be done every single week for which he or she collects the payment. Why on earth
column36: is an applicant of PIAB not required to do likewise given that applicants are often making claims for tens of thousands of euro
column37: or often hundreds of thousands? Why is there no provision in law applying penalties for false or misleading statements to PIAB? Is the Minister of State aware of how many claims PIAB exposes as being false or misleading each year? How would he assess the knock-on effects of such claims on the work of PIAB and on insurance costs? As matters stand
column38: any person can submit an application seeking damages that is a tissue of lies from start to finish but face no consequences for doing so. Does the Government have a reason for this? Will it justify further inaction?

column1: #JamesBrowne	unknown-#JamesBrowne-party	unknown-#JamesBrowne-dob	unknown-#JamesBrowne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-06-15 00:00:00	Gnó an tSeanaid - Business of Seanad	16	I thank Senator Mullen for raising this important matter
column2: which I am taking on behalf of Minister of State
column3: Deputy Robert Troy
column4: who unfortunately cannot be here this morning. PIAB is an agency under the remit of the Department of Enterprise
column5: Trade and Employment that independently assesses claims for compensation arising from personal injuries. It can assess claims only where both parties
column6: namely
column7: the claimant and respondent
column8: consent to an assessment. Under the PIAB process
column9: a respondent has 90 days to carry out an appropriate examination of the facts relating to a claim before deciding whether to proceed with the PIAB process. By proceeding with the PIAB process
column10: the respondent would have considered the claimant's case and satisfied himself or herself as to its merits or otherwise. Where liability is an issue
column11: or the circumstances of a claim are disputed
column12: the respondent
column13: generally an insurer
column14: will refuse an assessment of the claim by PIAB so he or she can investigate the matter. In those circumstances
column15: PIAB will release the case and provide authorisation to a claimant to proceed to litigation if he or she so wishes. PIAB does not investigate the circumstances of claims or address the issue of liability. This is because PIAB is not a court. It is an administrative body that assesses and makes awards for personal injuries based on the personal injury guidelines following consent of the parties and without recourse to court. The determination of liability is
column16: by its nature
column17: a matter of judgment for which a court is the appropriate body and for which a court can take into account the relevant matters presented to it by all parties. Cases that proceed to court are subject to the Civil Liability and Courts Act 2004. Section 14 of the Act provides that any party to a personal injuries action who has falsely sworn an affidavit is guilty of an offence. Sections 25 and 26 address the matter of false evidence and fraudulent actions and section 29 sets out the penalties for persons found guilty of such acts
column18: including fines of up to €100
column19: 000 or up to ten years in prison
column20: or both. The investigation of fraud is a matter for An Garda Síochána. Any individuals or companies that believe they are the victims of fraud should report it to the Garda. PIAB co-operates fully with any requests for information from the Garda. The PIAB model
column21: which is based on the consent of parties
column22: works. It saves tens of millions of euro annually that would otherwise be paid in costs by the parties
column23: and ultimately by policyholders. Through PIAB
column24: claims can be settled without the need for many of the costs associated with litigation
column25: which can contribute to the high cost of settling and the cost of insurance. A range of actions to mitigate insurance fraud are set out in the Government's Action Plan for Insurance Reform. These actions are led
column27: by the Minister for Justice. Of particular importance is the Criminal Justice (Perjury and Related Offences) Bill 2018
column28: currently before the Houses and which I hope will pass through the Seanad today. When enacted
column29: this will provide a deterrent to the making of misleading or fraudulent statements. It will be a welcome development
column30: particularly regarding the cost of insurance. As part of the action plan
column33: is currently finalising legislative proposals to enhance and reform PIAB and will engage with the Seanad on strengthening the PIAB process in the near future. PIAB is not a court. It is an administrative body for assessing and either party can reject the process if he or she feels unsatisfied with it.

I have said here before that those involved often seem more interested in the rhetoric and grabbing headlines than in tackling the problem. Judges and the legal profession have been unfairly blamed. There was even a nonsensical kite flown about a potential constitutional amendment to cap awards. The Judicial Council guidelines on awards have come into effect

column17: of course

#EmerCurrie	unknown-#EmerCurrie-party	unknown-#EmerCurrie-dob	unknown-#EmerCurrie-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-06-15 00:00:00	Gnó an tSeanaid - Business of Seanad	23	I want to talk to the Minister of State about the newly found localism that Covid has brought about. column2: people were forced to stay within a radius of 2 km to 5 km but a side effect was that they discovered what was under their own noses and grew to appreciate it more. We were moving towards a sense of that anyway because of concerns over sustainability and because people were sick of their lifestyles
column3: always being on the go
column4: congestion and chasing their tails.In many families the Covid pandemic brought about another way of doing things. It was not for everybody
column5: particularly people who are working from home in cramped rented accommodation. For many people a new localism is a positive thing. We have responded to this. The rural strategy has been launched. The Government has acknowledged the opportunity for people to choose where they can live. The Department of Enterprise
column6: Trade and Employment has delivered a legal framework on the code of practice to disconnect and we will see further funding in budget 2022. column13: in places like Ongar
column14: Blanchardstown village and Castleknock
column15: people do not have the space for home offices. The Government wants to encourage spending in the local economy. We do not want people to be working from home all the time. We want to see them in our main streets and getting the benefit of that. We need to think of all the families who live in suburban areas and the parents who would benefit from working closer to home. column16: whereas remote working gives flexibility to more people.  Funds are available for people who want to open co-working hubs in rural places but there is very little when it comes to suburban and urban areas where I live which would really benefit from them.

column12: scallop
column13: shrimp

column1: #JamesBrowne	unknown-#JamesBrowne-party	unknown-#JamesBrowne-dob	unknown-#JamesBrowne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-06-15 00:00:00	Gnó an tSeanaid - Business of Seanad	29	I apologise on behalf of the Minister

column4: unfortunately
column5: cannot be here. I thank Senator O’Donovan for providing me with the opportunity to update the House on the matters pertaining to this very important issue. For the record
column6: I should state at the outset that the strict legal position in relation to the revocation of Ireland's control plan is that the monitoring and control of fishing vessels within Ireland's exclusive fisheries zone are matters for the Irish control authorities. column7: all operational issues of this nature are exclusively for the Sea-Fisheries Protection Authority and the Naval Service. Therefore
column8: the Minister
column9: Deputy McConalogue
column10: is expressly precluded from getting involved in operational matters such as this. By way of background
column11: as the Senator will be aware
column12: following an EU Commission audit in 2018

column14: CFP. The findings of the inquiry were communicated to Ireland in December 2020. The findings of the administrative inquiry deemed the Irish control and sanctioning systems as unsatisfactory

column16: under statute
column17: the Minister is precluded from getting involved in them. The Department of Agriculture
column18: Food and the Marine has commenced a process of engagement with the EU Commission in association with the SFPA
column19: which is responsible for operational matters. In the context of this engagement

column28: the control plan does not minimise the risk of ... [systemic] manipulation of weighing pelagic catches in Ireland and the under-declaration of catches by operators.Since the Commission's decision was announced
column29: I understand the SFPA has engaged directly with the industry to ensure that fishers and processors are familiar with the changes that are required to comply with EU weighing requirements
column30: and continues to engage with the industry on this matter. column32: I would like to reassure the Senator and the House that the Government takes the Commission's findings relating to fisheries control failures
column33: including the revocation of Ireland's control plan
column34: very seriously. We are fully committed to having an effective
column35: dissuasive and proportionate system of fisheries control in place.

#JamesBrowne	unknown-#JamesBrowne-party	unknown-#JamesBrowne-dob	unknown-#JamesBrowne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-06-15 00:00:00	Gnó an tSeanaid - Business of Seanad	104	The second group of amendments comprises amendments Nos. 7 to 9
column2: inclusive
column3: amendment No. 20 and amendment No. 21. This group of amendments relates directly to the offence of perjury and subornation of perjury. Amendment No. 7
column4: in section 2
column5: amends the definition of perjury so that it may apply to statements of truth in addition to sworn statements and affidavits. Amendment No. 8 is necessary to provide a clear definition of "subornation of perjury" in section 3. Subornation of perjury means persuading another person to commit perjury. This is a serious matter because of the effect it has on legal proceedings. The section provides that a prosecution for subornation of perjury can take place even where the person committing the perjury in question has not been convicted of the offence. The perpetrator of the offence of subordination of perjury must know or be reckless to the fact that the other person is committing perjury. This means that he or she must at least know there is a significant risk that perjury would be committed as a result of his or her actions yet press ahead regardless. Amendment No. 9 separates the different types of references already on our Statute Book into Schedules for clarity. Amendment No. 20 is a technical amendment to adjust slightly the wording used in the current section 8 to match the more usual formulation used in primary legislation. Amendment No. 21 is a technical amendment to the current section 10 to bring it into line with other provisions of the Bill.

column1: #JamesBrowne	unknown-#JamesBrowne-party	unknown-#JamesBrowne-dob	unknown-#JamesBrowne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2021-06-15 00:00:00	Gnó an tSeanaid - Business of Seanad	155	I thank the Members for supporting the former Senator
column2: Pádraig Ó Céidigh
column3: in bringing this Bill in the first place. It shows the importance of relying on all the abilities across the Houses and not simply on Departments. That is an important point to make. I wish to pay tribute to my Department for taking up this Bill and for the hard work the officials have put into it as well as the work of previous and current Ministers in the Department. Mr. Ó Céidigh introduced this legislation in 2018 as a Private Members' Bill. He was instrumental in the successful passage of the Bill as was the cross-party support. A debt of gratitude is owed to the former Senator. Historically
column4: it has been difficult to prosecute perjury and subornation of perjury as a common law offence. This new Bill will make it effective. It will streamline the process and make prosecutions far easier by putting the offence on a clear statutory footing. Perjury
column5: fraudulent claims and exaggerated claims have a significant impact on our businesses and on the premiums people have to pay. They undermine justice when people can get away with making false statements. It is part of the plan of the Government on insurance reform. As was rightly pointed out by Senator Ward
column6: this will apply to family law and other civil law cases. It will also apply to criminal law because sometimes we see people bringing forward false alibis. This will not only make it an offence for people to perjure but to seek for someone to perjure as well. It is a historic Bill in that this will be codified for the first time. It is most welcome and I thank the Houses for their support.
